Description: An introduction to the classical Latin language in the context of ancient Roman culture.
A continuation of the introduction to the classical Latin language in the context of ancient Roman culture.
Excerpts from Latin literature with emphasis on translation into English.
Excerpts from Latin literature with emphasis on both prose (e.g., Caesar, Cicero) and poetry (Vergil, Catullus).

Readings in Cicero's orations and philosophical works, stressing rhetorical techniques. Consideration of Cicero's
role in Roman history and his place in Latin literature.

A study of the Latin text of Vergil's Aeneid stressing the poetry of the language. Consideration of entire poem
and its impact on Latin literature.

(Repeatable for credit)Workshops individually designed to provide instruction and training in latin studies. S u
graded.

Prerequisites: LAT 36170 or LAT 36171; and special approval.
Description:
Study of ancient inscriptions (funerary, career, documentary, graffiti, etc.) preserved on any kind of durable
material, with focus on cultural information necessary to understand the content and significance of the
inscriptions under investigation.

Prerequisites: LAT 36170 or LAT 36171; and special approval.
Description:
(Slashed with LAT 51304) Stylistics and cultural context of Roman historians. Readings from any of the
following: Caesar, Livy, Suetonius, Tacitus.

Prerequisites: LAT 36170 or LAT 36171; and special approval.
Description:
Stylistics, history and cultural context of Roman comedy and satire. Readings from any of the following: Plautus,
Terence, Horace, Juvenal, Persius, Martial.

Prerequisites: LAT 36170 or LAT 36171; and special approval.
Description:
(Slashed with LAT 51306) Stylistics, history and cultural context of Latin epic poetry. Readings from any of the
following: Vergil, Lucretius, Ovid, Lucan, Statius.

(Slashed with LAT 51307) Stylistics, history and cultural context of Latin lyric and elegiac poetry. Readings from
any of the following: Catullus, Horace, Propertius, Tibullus, Ovid.

Prerequisites: LAT 36170 or LAT 36171; and special approval.
Description:
Stylistics, history and cultural context of Latin oratory and the Latin epistle. Readings from any of the following:
Cicero, Seneca, Pliny.

Description: (Repeatable for credit)Investigation of problems in Latin literature or linguistics.
Analysis of prose models; writing of connected Latin prose with attention to the Latin idiom.

(Repeatable for credit) Consideration of a major prose author such as Pliny the Younger, Livy, Tacitus or
Suetonius.

Use of lexical tools, bibliographies and corpora specific to research in Classics and Latin. Conventions of
scholarship in the discipline of Classics. To be taken in conjunction with a 50000 or 60000-level course in Latin
literature.
